messageBody:
On 8/7/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
>
> My sinsere apologies to you Cédric, I didn't realise that the
> statement that upset me was not written by you. I jumped to my guns
> too quickly.


Thanks for posting this rectification, Joakim, I appreciate.

Look, I'm trying to build a bridge here.

On one hand, we have a small (very small) population of people who've put
testing at the forefront of every single engineering task they undertake
every day at the exclusion of anything else.

On the other hand, we have the "rest of the world", which is slowly waking
up to the values of automated testing but is also dealing with massive code
bases that were not only *not* designed for automated testing, but for which
automated testing might simply be impossible to implement (and yes, I can
come up with a few examples that will make the most radical TDD
practitioners go very humble).

I don't have anything to sell here. I'm not a consultant, I don't get paid
if you use TestNG or if you do more automated testing. But I've worked on
both sides of the fence: I love testing, I like TDD to a certain extent,
but I'm also seeing a few flaws and gaps in reality between what I read and
the rest of the industry, and because of that, I feel that I can offer a
perspective that both sides can relate to.

When somebody posts on this mailing-list asking for help because they can't
follow to the letter principles explained in extreme books, I feel as a
personal obligation to tell them "It's okay, let's take it one step at a
time".

Soon, I'll post a few additional thoughts on where I see limitations (and
sometimes flaws) in TDD and code coverage, and I have no doubt that some of
you will choose to interpret that as "Cedric hates TDD" and "Cedric doesn't
believe in code coverage" but I hope the rest of you will see beyond that
and use these arguments to make educated decisions on when and where to use
the best tool for your job.

Because the truth is that there is no silver bullet to write good code, and
you should be very skeptical of anyone who is trying to convince you
otherwise.

--
Cédric
http://testng.org
